alert.note: Alert for Central Middlesex County; Eastern Essex; Eastern Franklin; Eastern Hampden; Eastern Hampshire; Eastern Norfolk; Northern Worcester; Northwest Middlesex County; Southeast Middlesex; Southern Worcester; Suffolk; Western Essex; Western Franklin; Western Hampden; Western Hampshire; Western Norfolk (Massachusetts) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 27 at 5:33PM EST by NWS Boston
info.description: ...BRIEF HEAVY SNOW SHOWERS AND POSSIBLE SNOW SQUALLS THIS EVENING... As of 530 PM Sunday...An Arctic cold front was making its way southeastward from central New Hampshire into southern Vermont. Bands of snow showers and snow squalls were associated with this cold front. These snow showers and possible snow squalls will move southward into most of Massachusetts along and north of the Massachusetts Turnpike between 6 PM and 10 PM. Weakening trends are expected as these snow showers and snow squalls move south of the Massachusetts Turnpike. Snow squalls are intense but short-lived bursts of heavy snow and gusty winds, which have the potential to reduce visibility to local whiteout levels for about 15 to 30 minutes. These conditions could disorient unsuspecting drivers. While up to an inch of new snow is expected, the main hazard with snow squalls is the rapid reduction in visibility. Motorists are advised to be alert to rapidly changing visibility and driving conditions in heavy snow showers or possible snow squalls. Consider delaying travel or pulling to the side of the road until visibility improves. Have a way to receive later statements or possible snow squall warnings as conditions warrant.
